Valued_Change: WTP for Habitat for species - Mangrove restoration scenario
Site_Condition: the Lagoon suffers from heavy development, mangrove destruction, wastewater pollution and overexploitation (Gilders, 2018; Yáñez-Arancibia et al., 2011). Over the past two decades, the Lagoon has decreased with 23 % in size due to land reclamation for infrastructural projects. (Vermeij & van den Brink, 2010). Furthermore, sewage inflow is common due to lacking sewage treatment facilities. These pressures have deteriorated the ecological integrity of the Lagoon and threaten to impair the capacity of the Lagoon to provide essential ecosystem services for the local population. The bad water quality of the Lagoon resulting from human activities also has detrimental impacts on the nearby coral reefs, which are of high ecological and economic value
Reference: Duijndam, S., van Beukering, P., Fralikhina, H., Molenaar, A., & Koetse, M. (2020). Valuing a Caribbean coastal lagoon using the choice experiment method: The case of the Simpson Bay Lagoon, Saint Martin. Journal for Nature Conservation, 56, 125845.

Site_Condition: the Lagoon suffers from heavy development, mangrove destruction, wastewater pollution and overexploitation (Gilders, 2018; Yáñez-Arancibia et al., 2011). Over the past two decades, the Lagoon has decreased with 23 % in size due to land reclamation for infrastructural projects. (Vermeij & van den Brink, 2010). Furthermore, sewage inflow is common due to lacking sewage treatment facilities. These pressures have deteriorated the ecological integrity of the Lagoon and threaten to impair the capacity of the Lagoon to provide essential ecosystem services for the local population. The bad water quality of the Lagoon resulting from human activities also has detrimental impacts on the nearby coral reefs, which are of high ecological and economic value
Reference: Duijndam, S., van Beukering, P., Fralikhina, H., Molenaar, A., & Koetse, M. (2020). Valuing a Caribbean coastal lagoon using the choice experiment method: The case of the Simpson Bay Lagoon, Saint Martin. Journal for Nature Conservation, 56, 125845.

Valued_Change: Value of ecosystem service under the Open Haringvliet (restoration) scenario
Site_Condition: The Haringvliet was closed in 1971 by the Haringvlietdam. Opening it will require removal of this dam (see Fig. 6). This will reintroduce tide in the whole area up to the Biesbosch. From the west salt water will enter a part of the area, while freshwater from the rivers will flow through the arm to the sea. The freshwater-saltwater gradient is restored. The location of this gradient zone will depend on theamount of fresh water that will flow in, but will occur mostly in the west area of the Haringvliet. Triggered by tide erosion and sedimentation processes will form channels and islands again. The shallow zones along the dikes will rise because of sedimentation and wetlands will develop here. Figure 5 shows the current and a future scenario of how the Haringvliet could be developed with restored estuarine dynamics. It should be underlined that this map shows a global, possible future scenario that formed input for this research. The actual future development can differ from this scenario. Current dikes have insufficient height and can be replaced by ?Klimaatdijken? (climate dikes) which are dikes that are unusually broad and because of their large area and slope provide opportunity for functions like recreation, residence and agriculture. The area outside the dikes is enlarged by placing the Klimaatdijken more inland, (considering urban areas) to create a strip of land subject to tide and sedimentation. Here wetlands will (re-)establish, providing the opportunity of recreation, contributing to the storm buffering capacity and also support plant and animal populations by supporting the local ecosystem. Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.
Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

Here wetlands will (re-)establish, providing the opportunity of recreation, contributing to the storm buffering capacity and also support plant and animal populations by supporting the local ecosystem. Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.
Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

Valued_Change: Value of ecosystem service under the Open Haringvliet (restoration) scenario
Site_Condition: The Haringvliet was closed in 1971 by the Haringvlietdam. Opening it will require removal of this dam (see Fig. 6). This will reintroduce tide in the whole area up to the Biesbosch. From the west salt water will enter a part of the area, while freshwater from the rivers will flow through the arm to the sea. The freshwater-saltwater gradient is restored. The location of this gradient zone will depend on theamount of fresh water that will flow in, but will occur mostly in the west area of the Haringvliet. Triggered by tide erosion and sedimentation processes will form channels and islands again. The shallow zones along the dikes will rise because of sedimentation and wetlands will develop here. Figure 5 shows the current and a future scenario of how the Haringvliet could be developed with restored estuarine dynamics. It should be underlined that this map shows a global, possible future scenario that formed input for this research. The actual future development can differ from this scenario. Current dikes have insufficient height and can be replaced by ?Klimaatdijken? Triggered by tide erosion and sedimentation processes will form channels and islands again. The shallow zones along the dikes will rise because of sedimentation and wetlands will develop here. Figure 5 shows the current and a future scenario of how the Haringvliet could be developed with restored estuarine dynamics. It should be underlined that this map shows a global, possible future scenario that formed input for this research. The actual future development can differ from this scenario. Current dikes have insufficient height and can be replaced by ?Klimaatdijken? (climate dikes) which are dikes that are unusually broad and because of their large area and slope provide opportunity for functions like recreation, residence and agriculture. The area outside the dikes is enlarged by placing the Klimaatdijken more inland, (considering urban areas) to create a strip of land subject to tide and sedimentation. Here wetlands will (re-)establish, providing the opportunity of recreation, contributing to the storm buffering capacity and also support plant and animal populations by supporting the local ecosystem. Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.
Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

Valued_Change: Value of ecosystem service under the Open Haringvliet (restoration) scenario
Site_Condition: The Haringvliet was closed in 1971 by the Haringvlietdam. Opening it will require removal of this dam (see Fig. 6). This will reintroduce tide in the whole area up to the Biesbosch. From the west salt water will enter a part of the area, while freshwater from the rivers will flow through the arm to the sea. The freshwater-saltwater gradient is restored. The location of this gradient zone will depend on theamount of fresh water that will flow in, but will occur mostly in the west area of the Haringvliet. Triggered by tide erosion and sedimentation processes will form channels and islands again. The shallow zones along the dikes will rise because of sedimentation and wetlands will develop here. Figure 5 shows the current and a future scenario of how the Haringvliet could be developed with restored estuarine dynamics. It should be underlined that this map shows a global, possible future scenario that formed input for this research. The actual future development can differ from this scenario. Current dikes have insufficient height and can be replaced by ?Klimaatdijken? (climate dikes) which are dikes that are unusually broad and because of their large area and slope provide opportunity for functions like recreation, residence and agriculture. The area outside the dikes is enlarged by placing the Klimaatdijken more inland, (considering urban areas) to create a strip of land subject to tide and sedimentation. Here wetlands will (re-)establish, providing the opportunity of recreation, contributing to the storm buffering capacity and also support plant and animal populations by supporting the local ecosystem. Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.
Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

(climate dikes) which are dikes that are unusually broad and because of their large area and slope provide opportunity for functions like recreation, residence and agriculture. The area outside the dikes is enlarged by placing the Klimaatdijken more inland, (considering urban areas) to create a strip of land subject to tide and sedimentation. Here wetlands will (re-)establish, providing the opportunity of recreation, contributing to the storm buffering capacity and also support plant and animal populations by supporting the local ecosystem. Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.
Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

Valued_Change: Value of ecosystem service under the Open Haringvliet (restoration) scenario
Site_Condition: The Haringvliet was closed in 1971 by the Haringvlietdam. Opening it will require removal of this dam (see Fig. 6). This will reintroduce tide in the whole area up to the Biesbosch. From the west salt water will enter a part of the area, while freshwater from the rivers will flow through the arm to the sea. The freshwater-saltwater gradient is restored. The location of this gradient zone will depend on theamount of fresh water that will flow in, but will occur mostly in the west area of the Haringvliet. Triggered by tide erosion and sedimentation processes will form channels and islands again. The shallow zones along the dikes will rise because of sedimentation and wetlands will develop here. Figure 5 shows the current and a future scenario of how the Haringvliet could be developed with restored estuarine dynamics. From the west salt water will enter a part of the area, while freshwater from the rivers will flow through the arm to the sea. The freshwater-saltwater gradient is restored. The location of this gradient zone will depend on theamount of fresh water that will flow in, but will occur mostly in the west area of the Haringvliet. Triggered by tide erosion and sedimentation processes will form channels and islands again. The shallow zones along the dikes will rise because of sedimentation and wetlands will develop here. Figure 5 shows the current and a future scenario of how the Haringvliet could be developed with restored estuarine dynamics. It should be underlined that this map shows a global, possible future scenario that formed input for this research. The actual future development can differ from this scenario. Current dikes have insufficient height and can be replaced by ?Klimaatdijken? (climate dikes) which are dikes that are unusually broad and because of their large area and slope provide opportunity for functions like recreation, residence and agriculture. The area outside the dikes is enlarged by placing the Klimaatdijken more inland, (considering urban areas) to create a strip of land subject to tide and sedimentation. Here wetlands will (re-)establish, providing the opportunity of recreation, contributing to the storm buffering capacity and also support plant and animal populations by supporting the local ecosystem. Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.
Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.
Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

Valued_Change: Value of ecosystem service under the Open Haringvliet (restoration) scenario
Site_Condition: The Haringvliet was closed in 1971 by the Haringvlietdam. Opening it will require removal of this dam (see Fig. 6). This will reintroduce tide in the whole area up to the Biesbosch. From the west salt water will enter a part of the area, while freshwater from the rivers will flow through the arm to the sea. The freshwater-saltwater gradient is restored. The location of this gradient zone will depend on theamount of fresh water that will flow in, but will occur mostly in the west area of the Haringvliet. Triggered by tide erosion and sedimentation processes will form channels and islands again. The shallow zones along the dikes will rise because of sedimentation and wetlands will develop here. Figure 5 shows the current and a future scenario of how the Haringvliet could be developed with restored estuarine dynamics. It should be underlined that this map shows a global, possible future scenario that formed input for this research. The actual future development can differ from this scenario. Current dikes have insufficient height and can be replaced by ?Klimaatdijken? (climate dikes) which are dikes that are unusually broad and because of their large area and slope provide opportunity for functions like recreation, residence and agriculture. The area outside the dikes is enlarged by placing the Klimaatdijken more inland, (considering urban areas) to create a strip of land subject to tide and sedimentation. Here wetlands will (re-)establish, providing the opportunity of recreation, contributing to the storm buffering capacity and also support plant and animal populations by supporting the local ecosystem. Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.

Figure 5 shows the current and a future scenario of how the Haringvliet could be developed with restored estuarine dynamics. It should be underlined that this map shows a global, possible future scenario that formed input for this research. The actual future development can differ from this scenario. Current dikes have insufficient height and can be replaced by ?Klimaatdijken? (climate dikes) which are dikes that are unusually broad and because of their large area and slope provide opportunity for functions like recreation, residence and agriculture. The area outside the dikes is enlarged by placing the Klimaatdijken more inland, (considering urban areas) to create a strip of land subject to tide and sedimentation. Here wetlands will (re-)establish, providing the opportunity of recreation, contributing to the storm buffering capacity and also support plant and animal populations by supporting the local ecosystem. Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.
Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

Valued_Change: Value of ecosystem service under the Open Haringvliet (restoration) scenario
Site_Condition: The Haringvliet was closed in 1971 by the Haringvlietdam. Opening it will require removal of this dam (see Fig. 6). This will reintroduce tide in the whole area up to the Biesbosch. From the west salt water will enter a part of the area, while freshwater from the rivers will flow through the arm to the sea. The freshwater-saltwater gradient is restored. The location of this gradient zone will depend on theamount of fresh water that will flow in, but will occur mostly in the west area of the Haringvliet. Triggered by tide erosion and sedimentation processes will form channels and islands again. The shallow zones along the dikes will rise because of sedimentation and wetlands will develop here. Figure 5 shows the current and a future scenario of how the Haringvliet could be developed with restored estuarine dynamics. It should be underlined that this map shows a global, possible future scenario that formed input for this research. The actual future development can differ from this scenario. Current dikes have insufficient height and can be replaced by ?Klimaatdijken? (climate dikes) which are dikes that are unusually broad and because of their large area and slope provide opportunity for functions like recreation, residence and agriculture. The area outside the dikes is enlarged by placing the Klimaatdijken more inland, (considering urban areas) to create a strip of land subject to tide and sedimentation. Here wetlands will (re-)establish, providing the opportunity of recreation, contributing to the storm buffering capacity and also support plant and animal populations by supporting the local ecosystem. Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.
Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

The area outside the dikes is enlarged by placing the Klimaatdijken more inland, (considering urban areas) to create a strip of land subject to tide and sedimentation. Here wetlands will (re-)establish, providing the opportunity of recreation, contributing to the storm buffering capacity and also support plant and animal populations by supporting the local ecosystem. Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.
Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

Valued_Change: Value of ecosystem service under the Open Haringvliet (restoration) scenario
Site_Condition: The Haringvliet was closed in 1971 by the Haringvlietdam. Opening it will require removal of this dam (see Fig. 6). This will reintroduce tide in the whole area up to the Biesbosch. From the west salt water will enter a part of the area, while freshwater from the rivers will flow through the arm to the sea. The freshwater-saltwater gradient is restored. The location of this gradient zone will depend on theamount of fresh water that will flow in, but will occur mostly in the west area of the Haringvliet. Triggered by tide erosion and sedimentation processes will form channels and islands again. The shallow zones along the dikes will rise because of sedimentation and wetlands will develop here. Figure 5 shows the current and a future scenario of how the Haringvliet could be developed with restored estuarine dynamics. It should be underlined that this map shows a global, possible future scenario that formed input for this research. The actual future development can differ from this scenario. The location of this gradient zone will depend on theamount of fresh water that will flow in, but will occur mostly in the west area of the Haringvliet. Triggered by tide erosion and sedimentation processes will form channels and islands again. The shallow zones along the dikes will rise because of sedimentation and wetlands will develop here. Figure 5 shows the current and a future scenario of how the Haringvliet could be developed with restored estuarine dynamics. It should be underlined that this map shows a global, possible future scenario that formed input for this research. The actual future development can differ from this scenario. Current dikes have insufficient height and can be replaced by ?Klimaatdijken? (climate dikes) which are dikes that are unusually broad and because of their large area and slope provide opportunity for functions like recreation, residence and agriculture. The area outside the dikes is enlarged by placing the Klimaatdijken more inland, (considering urban areas) to create a strip of land subject to tide and sedimentation. Here wetlands will (re-)establish, providing the opportunity of recreation, contributing to the storm buffering capacity and also support plant and animal populations by supporting the local ecosystem. Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.
Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.
Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

Valued_Change: Value of ecosystem service under the Open Haringvliet (restoration) scenario
Site_Condition: The Haringvliet was closed in 1971 by the Haringvlietdam. Opening it will require removal of this dam (see Fig. 6). This will reintroduce tide in the whole area up to the Biesbosch. From the west salt water will enter a part of the area, while freshwater from the rivers will flow through the arm to the sea. The freshwater-saltwater gradient is restored. The location of this gradient zone will depend on theamount of fresh water that will flow in, but will occur mostly in the west area of the Haringvliet. Triggered by tide erosion and sedimentation processes will form channels and islands again. The shallow zones along the dikes will rise because of sedimentation and wetlands will develop here. Figure 5 shows the current and a future scenario of how the Haringvliet could be developed with restored estuarine dynamics. It should be underlined that this map shows a global, possible future scenario that formed input for this research. The actual future development can differ from this scenario. Current dikes have insufficient height and can be replaced by ?Klimaatdijken? (climate dikes) which are dikes that are unusually broad and because of their large area and slope provide opportunity for functions like recreation, residence and agriculture. The area outside the dikes is enlarged by placing the Klimaatdijken more inland, (considering urban areas) to create a strip of land subject to tide and sedimentation. Here wetlands will (re-)establish, providing the opportunity of recreation, contributing to the storm buffering capacity and also support plant and animal populations by supporting the local ecosystem. Opening the Haringvlietdam will also influence the Voordelta (i.e. parts of Haringvlietdelta beyond the dam and adjacent coastal area), which is why this area was also included in the investigation. Taken together, the study area has a size of about 81.000 ha.
Reference: Bönhke-Heinrichs, A., & De Groot, R. S. (2010). A pilot study on the consequences of an Open Haringvliet-Scenario for changes in ecosystem services and their monetary value.

Valued_Change: Mean WTP for Management option (2) in which the three ecologically vulnerable zones become MPAs and economic activities are allowed, but strictly controlled - (Double Bound, Mail survey).
Site_Condition: Anthropogenic impacts on the shelf water have been significant for many years (e.g. [16]). The marine ecosystems are under in- tense pressure from fishing, nitrogen input (from air and major rivers draining into the North Sea, such as the Rhine), recreational use and habitat loss. The seabed is rich in oil and gas, and sand extraction provides valuable material for the construction in- dustry. All these resources are intensively exploited. Recent de- velopments include offshore wind farms and aquaculture, com- peting with existing commercial shipping interests for space in the North Sea.
Reference: Brouwer, R., Brouwer, S., Eleveld, M. A., Verbraak, M., Wagtendonk, A. J., & Van Der Woerd, H. J. (2016). Public willingness to pay for alternative management regimes of remote marine protected areas in the North Sea. Marine Policy, 68, 195-204.

The seabed is rich in oil and gas, and sand extraction provides valuable material for the construction in- dustry. All these resources are intensively exploited. Recent de- velopments include offshore wind farms and aquaculture, com- peting with existing commercial shipping interests for space in the North Sea.
Reference: Brouwer, R., Brouwer, S., Eleveld, M. A., Verbraak, M., Wagtendonk, A. J., & Van Der Woerd, H. J. (2016). Public willingness to pay for alternative management regimes of remote marine protected areas in the North Sea. Marine Policy, 68, 195-204.

Valued_Change: Total revenue from fish cleaning
Site_Condition: Recent data has shown that Statia is listed as one of the top dive destinations in the Caribbean with exceptionally healthy marine ecosystems with high bio-diversity and coral cover (St.Eustatius Marine Park Management Plan 2007). Within the Park are two actively- managed Reserves in which no fishing or anchoring is permitted to conserve marine biodiversity, protect fish stocks and promote sustainable tourism. In addition to regular mooring maintenance (dive, snorkel and yacht sites), patrols and research, the Marine Park works closely with three local dive centers to ensure that diving practices minimize impact on the reef.
Reference: Bervoets, T. (2010) Report on the Economic Valuation of St. Eustatius’ Coral Reef Resources STENAPA, National Parks Office.

Valued_Change: summer closure extension: banning all fishing gear in the moratorium season and extends its duration from 1 May to 1 September.
Site_Condition: The current trends of overfishing and biodiversity losses in the PRE are responsible for the collapse of many commercial marine fisheries established in the last century [36–39]. Furthermore, large increases in the number of fishing boats, improvements in fishing technology, and intensified fishing pressure on commercial fish species have resulted in a decline in the biomass of many large size and high-quality species and ‘prey release’ of some low valued species of small fish
Reference: Wang et al 2016 An integrated model for marine fishery management in the Pearl River Estuary- Linking socio-economic systems and ecosystems

Site_Condition: Ashtamudi estuary was designated as wetland of international importance by the Ramsar convention in 2002. But now the estuary is facing grave threats owing to the human as well as nonhuman interferences of various kinds. Valued_Change: Current flow of services without any change
Site_Condition: Mangrove habitat surrounding the Puttalam Lagoon area has been destructed for commercial purposes specially converting to prawn farms. It was estimated that around 3385ha of mangrove cover along the shores of Puttalam Lagoon, Dutch Bay and Portugal bay complex. A wide destruction has taken place form 1981 to 1992 leaving around 993 ha of mangrove cover in the Puttalam lagoon. (Amarasinghe and Perera, 1995).
Reference: ADB (2003). An economic evaluation of mangrove ecosystem and different fishing techniques in the Vanthavilluwa divisional secretariat in Puttalam district of Sri Lanka
